system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

Dear ___,

I hope this letter finds you in good health. I am writing to provide a summary of your recent hospitalization, which commenced with your admission on March 10, 2024, following a fall resulting in a loss of consciousness. At the time of admission, you exhibited a decreased level of consciousness, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 11, alongside slurred speech.

During the ensuing evaluation, a CT scan performed on March 11, 2024, revealed a hemorrhagic stroke localized to the right hemisphere, subsequently diagnosed as an unspecified intracerebral hemorrhage. Your initial laboratory findings indicated a slightly low hemoglobin level and elevated white blood cell count. Additionally, the coagulation profile demonstrated an elevated INR, suggestive of prolonged bleeding time.

In response to the cerebral edema identified, treatment with Mannitol at a dose of 0.25 g/kg every six hours was initiated. Furthermore, you were started on antihypertensive medications with dosages adjusted according to your blood pressure readings.

Over the course of your hospitalization, your neurological status remained monitored closely. Following the administration of appropriate therapy, your neurological evaluations noted persistent right-sided weakness and slurred speech, and although there was a lack of significant improvement initially, the safety measures were in place to prevent further incidents of falls.

Discussions were held regarding your prognosis and the care required moving forward. It is important to emphasize the necessity for continued monitoring and care to ensure your condition remains stable. Your discharge is planned with future evaluations and follow-up care being fundamental to your recovery process.

Please ensure to attend all scheduled follow-up appointments and adhere to the discharge plan discussed with you and your family. Should you have any questions or require further assistance, feel free to contact our office.

Wishing you a smooth recovery and good health.

Sincerely,

Dr. ___
